The viral phenom’s full-length debut cuts her modern pop sensibility with doses of historicism, embracing opposing energies with effortless swagger.
The Chicago rapper reflects on a bleak personal year and starts to recapture the optimism of his earlier music.
Greg Gonzalez has a lovely voice and a convincingly atmospheric take on dream pop, neither of which is well served by his two-dimensional fantasies.
On their duo debut, these guitarists step outside of free jazz and indie rock to offer a dozen surprisingly accessible and warm instrumentals.
The beloved Arizona emo band’s latest is a solid, self-aware effort, missing only a few risks.
While fame and fortune may’ve eluded them, the before-their-time New York City rockers’ influence is incalculable. Two decades on, their 1996 mini-LP sounds like a hiccup in the timeline.
Field recordings and ambient synthesizers combine to paint an evocative picture of the English countryside and its natural cycles of rot and rebirth.
The My Morning Jacket frontman collaborates with his hometown orchestra on a spiritual set of covers and originals over symphonic arrangements.
Accompanied by a newly published journal, this collection of synth odds and ends offers the rare opportunity to hear directly from an undersung icon of San Francisco’s gay disco scene.
With frank lyricism and clean production, the Australian songwriter and guitarist channels the confidence and immediacy of 2000s pop-rock.
This score for Justin Peck’s 2017 ballet, performed by the pianist Timo Andres, is a knotty but welcome addition to the singer-songwriter’s growing set of compositions for dance.
A mixtape made with half a dozen New York producers tilts the experimental producer’s left-field tendencies toward full-on dance music, but her signature oblique vocals remain a slippery presence.
Mtendere Mandowa, a veteran (and cult favorite) of the L.A. beat scene, gathers fresh collaborators for a set of effortless, shape-shifting tracks that make time stand still.
The Atlanta legend’s latest continues his consistent streak of mostly-good, sometimes-awkward new material.
The Queens rapper’s ninth album is full of the dizzyingly technical wordplay he’s made his trademark.
The 19-year-old singer-songwriter’s dual EP branches out from bedroom pop in a set of songs that consider the nuanced ways acting is tucked into our everyday lives.
The 21-year-old songwriter’s latest album is irritating enough to activate the mildest allergy to sincerity.
A document of the Detroit jazz collective’s later years captures a cast of dozens balancing local community with cultural staying power.
The synth-pop act’s third album, a rumination on loneliness in L.A., is its cleanest and most melodic, uncovering a previously obscured accessibility.

album: Everything Not Saved Will Be Lost Part 2
description: The English band’s second album this year isn’t a complement to its predecessor so much as just another iteration on a now-standard formula.
After a run of dates playing “obtuse, strange” music as a warm-up act for the xx, Sam Shepherd translates that experimental energy to an album of mischievous, melodic, stripped-down electronic music.
The Montreal synth-pop duo explore an alternate ’80s where ethereal, post-goth dream pop sounds almost indistinguishable from lush, adult-contemporary soft rock.
The adventurous musician and composer takes a step back toward a simpler, sparer sound.
Now down to a duo, the busy instrumentalists recruit Tune-Yards, Shabazz Palaces, and the singer of Yes for their aggressive fourth album.
A newly reissued private-press curio from 1975 captures the bygone sounds of daily life in Portland, Oregon, in dreamy, proto-ambient form.
The self-described “mutant” reps the New York underground at its freakiest on a fast-past, collage-heavy album of club rhythms, noise blasts, and unsettling humor.

album: There Existed an Addiction to Blood
description: Despite being based on a ’70s vampire film, the rap trio’s album is somehow their most bloodless project to date.
In the fourth volume of a proposed 12-part suite, the saxophonist fuses free jazz and folk spirituals into an ecstatic confrontation with American history at its darkest.
With harmonized guitars, spring-loaded rhythms, and snotty hooks, the Louisville band’s major-label debut is a well-earned success that doesn’t quite feel like a triumph.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the debut album by the Go-Go’s, a ’70s punk band that beat the odds to become ’80s pop superstars.
On the band’s sixth album, frontman Stephan Jenkins Peter Pans his way through an improbably infectious set of would-be hits.
After years of kicking against dance music’s strictures, Daniel Martin-McCormick delivers something close to a pure techno album. A product of turmoil, it’s a satisfyingly confident statement.
The idiosyncratic singer mixes R&B, ambient, and acoustic soul on her most accessible and fully-formed record, one that still feels like an open mic.
One of indie rock’s more consistent guitar bands charts its evolution with a career-spanning collection of non-album singles, B-sides, and cover songs.
The former Chairlift singer-songwriter centers her sweeping solo debut on her powerful voice, crafting love songs about the moment of surrender, the pain preceding it, and the euphoria after.
Pushing beyond his customary dancefloor focus, the French-Canadian producer twists club influences and collaborative input into a textured, exploratory sound, both intimate and immense.
The duo’s third album is a nostalgic indie-pop rumination on suburban teenhood that thrums with hopeful energy. The best songs are like dispatches from a cracking cocoon.
On his dense but meticulously rendered new album, the British folk singer uses grander pop arrangements to wade into the barbarism of modern life.
The Kenyan producer occupies his own switchbacking lane, blending global bass music and regional African rhythms with bits of grime, trap, and drum’n’bass.
The final album from the punk trio captures everything that was bratty, tender, and unforgettable about its leading force, Kim Shattuck, who passed away earlier this year.
On her self-titled sophomore effort, Laetitia Tamko leaps with both feet into new sounds and new horizons.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Bryan Ferry and Brian Eno’s glam-rock, art-school masterpiece.
The breakout NY rapper’s emotionally affecting, piano-heavy street tales start to run together at 17 tracks.

album: FLY or DIE II: bird dogs of paradise
description: The New York trumpeter and bandleader’s second album is darker, denser, and more experimental than its predecessor, but no less resonant.
After 38 years of making music, Kim Gordon’s thrilling solo debut lives at the vanguard of sound and performance, shot through with the beautiful, unsparing noise that has always defined her art.
A new box set of the legendary post-punk label’s first two years gathers chestnuts from Joy Division and the Durutti Column alongside rarities, oddities, dead ends, and some stunning graphic design.
Chicago’s least-relaxed band doubles their personnel and scales up their sound for a set of unnerving new wave.
Two figures of underground rap—Philly’s Sadhugold and Virginia’s Ohbliv—team up for a politically blunted, cult rap record in the making.
Malcom Lacey’s long-running electro-acoustic project feels like a window into someone’s private world.
The latest tape from the 20-year-old rapper is dense and mystic. MAVI delivers revelations from the shadows, concealed and mysterious, in search of fresh air and sunlight.
With his intense baritone voice, Devon Welsh travels deep into the feelings of isolation and introspection with grace and beauty.
What does it mean to get older in punk? Were the good old days ever that good? Though the titles change, the Pennsylvania band’s song remains the same.
The prolific Maryland rapper is alternately serious, silly, and soulful.
The Pittsburgh-based producer makes undeniably heavy music, combining hardcore techno, drum’n’bass, and footwork and sprinkling it with a bit of frivolity and chaos.
The ’90s alt-rockers’ first new album in more than 20 years has the vibe of a beloved record that was, for whatever reason, sitting on a shelf.
Forty years into his career, Nick Cave emerges with one of his most powerful albums yet, an endlessly giving and complex meditation on mortality and our collective grief.

album: Phantom Rhythm 幽靈節奏 (幽霊リズム)
description: The Beijing-based post-punk duo stack garage instrumentation, Ali Farka Touré melodies, and dissonance without a whiff of the baroque.
The second landmark album this year from Big Thief is raw, tactile, and essential. The intimate songs zoom in on a band that feels, at this moment, totally invincible.
Stepping away from the overt historicism of previous recordings, the guitarist opts for a subtler—but just as expressive—investigation of folk and blues.
On his bleak new album, woods doubles down on the misery that snakes through all his music.
After fusing J-Pop and heavy metal to great fanfare, the duo recruit international guests to expand their sound into even more unlikely hybrids.

album: On a Clear Day I Can See You Forever
description: The Scandinavian synthesizer maven pays dusts off dozens of arcane, vintage machines in an all-hardware studio recording meant to summon the spirit of bygone circuitry.
Velvety, ’90s-inspired deep house and industrial-punk sing-shouting make for a surprisingly complementary contrast.
The noise duo’s seventh album is the most life-affirming and accessible music they’ve ever made.
Chromatics set their surprise “seventh” album at the witching hour, telling a sometimes-muddled tale of heartbroken lovers reaching out to the spirit realm.
The newly reissued landmark debut from the Amityville emo band takes heartbreak, jealousy, and depression to an operatic intensity, but does so with sharp wit, a knowing wink, and oh so many hooks.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the auspicious debut that sent a 23-year-old guitarist into the stratosphere.
The Queens band WIVES channel the bygone squalor of NYC’s Y2K rock renaissance.
The celebrated avant-garde composer’s final work is a shrine to ecstatic disorientation.
Building atop a wobbly foundation of post-punk totems, the Glaswegian sextet make complicated songs sound fun.
On his fifth album, executive-produced by Q-Tip, Danny Brown ascends to a sort of hip-hop classicist nirvana and remains one of the most inventive and dimensional rappers working today.
Aided by Nels Cline, Marc Ribot, and Esperanza Spalding, the New York pianist and her band mix lyrical song form, turntablism, and avant-garde strategies in unusually fluid fashion.
The Australian multi-instrumentalist and songwriter’s second album finds a home in the shadowy space between post-punk, trip-hop, and lo-fi folk.
The shoegaze band’s third album is another portrait of addiction and recovery, but this time there’s no suggestion of a victory lap. The lyrics may wallow, but the music soars.
The trio’s debut is an exercise in post-punk and no-wave galvanism crafted from throbbing bass, tight-zipped drumbeats, and buzzing synths.
Wilco’s 11th album is direct and spacious, centering on the beauty of quiet revelation.
Throwing open his studio doors, the pianist aims for a loose, mixtape-like vibe, but the stacked guest list yields a scattershot party that only ends up overstaying its own welcome.
The 23-year-old Atlanta singer’s slow-groove R&B plays out like a telenovela, feeling irresistibly fresh, messy, and human.
The New York rapper’s highly anticipated debut album is another big, long flex from one of the most skilled rappers to emerge in the last five years.
After nearly breaking up and instead making their best album in years, the once-restless Japanese trio become something new again: self-satisfied.
Working without his longtime collaborator Scott Hirsch, M.C. Taylor enlists guests Jenny Lewis and Aaron Dessner as he explores the heaviest questions and realizes there are no answers.
The Charlotte, North Carolina rapper's debut finds him in his sweet spot—which is to say, demolition mode.

album: Love From the Planet Gong: The Virgin Years 1973-75
description: A mammoth box set of Daevid Allen’s prog-rock project makes a virtue of its excesses, capturing the band’s monumental strangeness.
The breathtaking songs of Angel Olsen’s fifth album are fleshed out by a 12-piece string section and deliver grand gestures about romance, authenticity, and being simply at the mercy of how we feel.
Animated with a new intensity, the Cornwall band’s fifth album may be its most ingenious and immersive mix of folk and rock yet.
On her alluring and unnerving new album, the Melbourne singer-songwriter adopts a digital alter-ego to explore real-life human strife.
The Brooklyn drill artist follows up his two-year-old hit “No Suburban” with a grim and terse debut LP.
The 20-year-old singer-songwriter’s clear vocals and candid lyrics feel at home in the Philadelphia DIY scene that raised her.
The New York-based composer’s third album spotlights piano and vibraphone, as attuned to the notes struck as to the overtones produced and their natural decay.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit an essential greatest hits album, one that brought ABBA indefinite fame.
The cosmic fusion group skewers the jazz-trio format as it’s typically understood, flipping the minimalist palette into an electrifying, apocalyptic sound.
The Thailand-born and Sweden-raised rapper offers a dreamy, melancholic, and abstracted take on mumble rap.
The Berlin producer is unafraid to throw a wrench into her steady grooves, and her latest disregards clubland’s status quo for more imaginative terrain.
Long-lost soundtrack recordings by the saxophonist’s powerhouse quartet, made shortly after 1964’s   sessions, capture the band at the peak of its cohesion.
Assisted by the pianist Phillip Bush and colleagues in the percussion ensemble Meridian, the American composer tests conventional notions of musical narrative.
The fourth album from the country outlaw is another left-turn with synth-rock at its scuzziest, boogie-rock at its cheesiest, all held together by Simpson’s fearless songwriting.
The Boston rockers’ third album wears its radicalism with confidence, and the untimely death of the band’s guitarist lends their late-capitalist protest unfortunate urgency.
The electronic outfit’s exquisitely bleak new record, the first since bandmate Charlie Cooper passed away, often feels like the very stuff of music is being torn apart.
The Brooklyn band skewers our collective relationship with social media—as well as their own—in noisy punk thrashers that are clever, incisive, and frequently very funny.

album: In the Morse Code of Brake Lights
description: Though a sense of doom lurks at the heart of the venerable band’s eighth album, they remain determined to keep classic guitar-pop alive by slyly twisting and expanding the form.
On their first new album since 2011, Vivian Girls jump back into fried guitar, loose percussion, and fast and easy repetition, as if they’d simply woken up from an eight-year nap.
The new box set includes demos, a live show, and a fascinating, stripped-down remix of the band’s 1989 album   that reveals an alternate history of one of their most divisive records.
The British psych-rockers’ third album boasts studied musicianship and strong arrangements—and very little else.
The follow up to 2016's revelatory   offers another showcase for the Baton Rouge rapper's fully formed and gloriously weird personality.
On his third album, the smooth Australian rocker leaves behind the arch character studies and tries to craft something more personal and sincere.
The Norwegian producer invents a Vocaloid-inspired feline character and retreats from the spotlit pop of his last album, returning to the introspective hush of his earlier work.
The genial Louisville rapper doesn’t have much of an identity, but he has a natural, low-stakes charm.
The shiny, beat-heavy sound of nu-blink-182 works in starts and stops, but feels half as fun as the band used to be.
On their first new album in four years, the Irish punk quartet channel pure, visceral panic through screeching sensory assaults and scrap-metal clang.

album: A Blaze in the Northern Sky
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a tense, beautiful, lo-fi landmark from the second wave of black metal.
On their ninth album, the twins revisit their roots, re-recording demos they wrote as teenagers and polishing them into poignant synth-pop gems.
A live recording from New York’s the Kitchen captures a rare kind of improv synergy between the versatile composer-percussionist and a pianist who rose to fame in Anthony Braxton’s quartet.
A collection of the duo’s 12" singles from the past six years proves their dancefloor nous but lacks the playfully eclectic spirit of previous albums.
Paired with drones from strings and struck bowls, the multimedia artist’s vivid readings from   offer the possibility of solace in sound itself.
Released 12 years after  , M83’s new collection of instrumentals doubles as a playful tribute to classic video-game soundtracks.
The beachy post-punk duo are at their most confident on their third album, with a sense of anguish that brings emotional depth to otherwise plain lyrics.
They’ve abandoned the crude wit of their debut, but the Seattle band’s fourth album still maintains the closeness of hanging out with friends in your living room.
The Swedish pop star’s fourth album contains some of her most vulnerable writing inside her clubbiest record.
Bridging the sepia warmth of Laurel Canyon with Appalachian folk, the Mountain Man singer’s solo debut revels in the magic of telling your own story.
Based on the paintings of Thilo Heinzmann and recorded by Brussels-based Echo Collective, this is the late Icelandic composer’s first proper work for string quartet alone.
The shadowy creators behind Topdown Dialectic make electronic music as ceaseless as it is cryptic.
The former Oasis frontman’s second solo album is pitched as a reintroduction, but forward motion—whether musical or personal—remains foreign to him.
The 22-year-old Instagram stuntman turned TikTok sensation has been minorly famous for only a few months, but he already sounds washed up.
The second album from the viral star is crowded with histrionic vocals, tired emotions, and petty grievances, leaving little room to actually enjoy his music.
On his most cohesive album in more than a decade, the re-energized songwriter imparts life lessons to the child he may never have.
The singer-songwriter’s pillowy guitar pop comforts on the surface but pulses with nightmarish visions beneath.
Luz Elena Mendoza follows her full-length   with an EP of introspective folk songs that understand just how visceral introspection can be.
The Ontario musician slings revolutionary sentiments and blood lust for authority over bittersweet alt-rock.
The exceptional solo debut from the Alabama Shakes singer-songwriter is a thrilling opus that pushes the boundaries of voice, sound, and soul to new extremes.
The soul singer’s latest is a multi-perspective, multi-genre examination of addiction and family breakdown.
An anthology of the emo pioneers’ complete works testifies to their thrift, their seriousness, and their towering legacy; it captures the essence of a crucial era in the genre’s history.
Leslie Bear’s second album could be about any ordinary American suburb, but the emotion behind her airy dream-pop makes it entirely personal.
After a string of muted releases, Ghost strains to recapture some of the old Wu fire.
On her breakout debut, the promising Melbourne rapper wrestles with big ideas about peace, family, and home.
The experimental rapper remains an impish writer and an athletic vocalist on his latest album, one that lays bare the sprawling collage in his fiery, fascinating brain.
Even with its imposing length and deep roster of collaborators, the ecstatic new album from Thurston Moore is arguably the most accessible entry point into his boundless experimental canon.
Channeling a wary mixture of dread and hope, the Polish indie rockers tighten the slackness of previous records into a potent fusion of post-hardcore and shoegaze.
The lead singer and songwriter for Blonde Redhead enlists Ryuichi Sakamoto, Greg Saunier, and others for a cottony swirl of an album where everything is quieter than everything else.
After the disappointing   and the serviceable  , the band shows signs of recapturing some of the spark of their classic albums.
For anyone who has ever fantasized about dissolving into the dancefloor, the debut solo album from techno artist Sam Barker is as close as it gets.
The Norwegian artist brings her heady, personal text into the world of dance music to create an affecting, transcendental album that lives on the boundary of pop and the avant-garde.
The enigmatic songwriter’s latest album is full of vignettes that shift to reveal and conceal themselves in ways too unpredictable to be easily faked. It might be his best yet.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the final album of Patsy Cline’s lifetime, a record that helped define country-pop.
The gorgeous and hypnotic second Lightning Bug album focuses more than ever on songwriter Audrey Kang’s hushed voice and simple, soulful lyrics.
On a thrilling slab of punk-jazz noise, the D.C. duo argues for the centrality of black American culture in the fight for the nation’s soul.
A casual approach gives rise to some of the English electro-indie band’s best songs in years. But for anyone not already misty-eyed with nostalgia, a meandering 17-track album is a hard sell.
The confrontational Brooklyn-based goth-metal outfit get a decadent box set that celebrates their sensuality and pathos as well as their uglier side.
On a dozen songs that transcend stereotypes of women in country music, this supergroup explores love, politics, and family.

album: The Time for Peace Is Now
description: Luaka Bop’s collection of ’70s rhythmic gospel rarities doesn’t feel like gospel in the traditional sense. These working musicians were deeply entwined with the funky, soulful sounds of their time.
These contemporary classical arrangements of traditional folk and Bonnie “Prince” Billy songs are lovely to listen to, but not so clear thematically.
Chicago’s local heroes grow up a little on their fourth album and lose some of their live-wire charm in the process.
Utilizing space recordings and scraps of poetry, the minimalist titan and his long-time collaborators grapple with humanity’s place in the universe.
Maya Bouldry-Morrison’s album is a celebration of the qualities—intimacy, ambiguity, physicality, release—that lead to dancefloor catharsis.
Adam Bainbridge’s production is always tasteful and seldom bad, but is only   when heightened by its guests.
Though the upstart British songwriter is a capable storyteller when he zeroes on a single topic, his debut is only intermittently transcendent.
On his meditative collaboration with the ambient guitarist Noveller and jazz trumpeter Leron Thomas, Iggy Pop turns inward.

album: Days of the Bagnold Summer (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
description: The indie-pop veterans mix together classics, rarities, some new songs, and instrumentals for the original film soundtrack.
On her most personal album to date, the UK experimental musician retains her focus on the ambiguities of the processed human voice while bringing traditional instrumentation to the fore.
With one of her most harrowing and powerful albums to date, Margaret Chardiet zeroes in on the locus where global horrors register on the individual.
The wonderfully anarchic British post-punk outfit tries out a little of everything on a promising debut EP.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit k.d. lang’s landmark 1992 album, an emotive and daring reinvention for the former country singer.
The debut album from Spillage Village founders Olu and WowGr8 is a whimsical, theatrical attempt to capture the inexhaustible magic of Atlanta.
On her fourth studio album, Greta Kline gamely stares down her middle twenties, that messy period where one’s early projections about the future tend to start unraveling.
Assisted by pianist Craig Taborn, the New York saxophonist’s longstanding trio balances minimalist stillness with post-bop freneticism, and covers Autechre and Jeff “Tain” Watts along the way.
With adventurous production and revealing writing, Charli XCX’s third studio album reflects an artist ready to commit to self-examination.
The songwriter’s most direct and brash album yet has no time for saxophones or keyboards. She gives specific, unpoetic examples and doesn’t mince words.

album: At the Party With My Brown Friends
description: Encased in swirls of dream-pop production, Katherine Paul’s second album represents a softer, more subtle sort of resistance.
The 17-year-old Queens rapper went viral off a certified hit, but his debut project is repetitive and uninspired.
The divisive pop star still gets bogged down in melancholy, but the charm of Post Malone’s third album is in his versatile voice and his ability to make a great hook inside pretty much any song.
Much like the UK composer’s score for Jonathan Glazer’s  ,   uses just a smattering of sounds to craft a world of deepening dread.
The Melbourne punk quartet sift through the grubbiest entrails of politics and internet culture, but their perspective sounds stilted.
The Baltimore synth-pop band’s latest might be their most explicitly political and theoretical work, tackling nothing less than the socio-psychological ravages of capitalism.
The major-label debut from the Maryland rapper clearly wants to appeal to the thinkers, but even at its most lucid, this loosely conceptual album falls well short of lofty ambitions.
The Chicago band’s second album dials back their beaming, golden-hour soft rock to a gentle lull.
Save for a few intimate highlights, Ben Gibbard continues to move in lockstep with his band’s bigger, bolder, more arena-ready sound.
Taylor Vick, a prolific Oakland songwriter and multi-instrumentalist, has made a generous and gorgeously empathetic chronicle of the aftermath of love.
Common’s latest is a loungy meditation on love and its many forms. It is at turns hopeful and naive.
Natasha Khan’s latest is a synth-pop love letter to the ’80s sci-fi and fantasy films of her youth.
The prog metal band’s fifth album is exactly what you’d expect from a project over a decade in the making: a more mature, sometimes exciting collection that feels both overworked and undercooked.
Georgia Flipo follows up her viral hit “About You” with a pop debut that hopes to re-bottle the song’s charm.
Translating alt-rock into pristine pop, the L.A. trio’s second album documents sex, drugs, and suicidal tendencies with less melodrama and more compassion.
On his second album in as many years, the perennially chill Toronto musician focuses on the guitar across a slow-motion, beatific collection of songs.
After some nebulous false starts, the former hardcore band has finally found space to carve their own lane in the crowded field of ’80s-indebted groups.

album: Whities 023 (The Act of Falling From the 8th Floor)
description: Three years after their debut collaboration, the Egyptian singer/poet/trumpeter and the German electronic trio reunite for six haunting tracks of socio-political despair and existential dread.
The North Carolina rap group (minus producer 9th Wonder) reunite for a warm, breezy LP that recalls the best of their original work.

album: LOVE AND AFFECTION FOR STUPID LITTLE BITCHES
description: Pop and noise make for strangely suited bedfellows on an album, by turns colorful and crushing, steeped in physical and psychic pain.
The New York party monsters change course, embracing the sounds of the ’90s and getting in touch with their feelings.
The pop music icon spends too much time looking back on a seemingly rushed, mostly forgettable collection of tracks.
On the sequel to 2017’s  , the Iranian Swedish singer’s dramatic take on soul finally bears fruit.

On her elegant and complex fifth album, Lana Del Rey sings exquisitely of freedom and transformation and the wreckage of being alive. It establishes her as one of America’s greatest living songwriters.
With tranquil, careful compositions that encourage introspection, the Vermont musician reflects on climate anxiety without succumbing to doom and gloom.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit JAY-Z’s second album, one that’s more gripping as a show of raw skill than it is as an act of myth-making.
The superstar’s eleventh studio album pairs her with famous friends ranging from Stevie Nicks to St. Vincent.
The duo depicts moments of great longing and melancholy on their sensual and gloomy new album.
Building on the legacy of ’90s riot grrrl and queercore, the Massachusetts punks’ debut album is a galvanizing thrill that insists on naming what some would ignore.
Titled after a game of computer solitaire, the Queens musician’s second album uses avant-pop songwriting to capture the nuances of tedium, to strangely captivating effect.
Rapsody’s third record is a triumph. The North Carolina MC unlocks her full skillset and brings her creativity and ingenuity to the fore.

album: Like the River Loves the Sea
description: The Kentucky folksinger’s fifth solo album strips down to acoustic instrumentation and her softly luminous voice, carving out a refuge where love and nature find solace in each other.
The 25-year-old Norwegian musician is a chameleonic vocal force. Her debut cushions heartache in shadowy, serpentine melodies and shoegaze guitars.

On his latest, Jidenna invokes a metaphorical highway to Africa, uniting the sounds of the sprawling diaspora. The music ranges from booming contemporary hip-hop to feather-light afropop and highlife.
On their absorbing and endearing new double album, John Dwyer's long-running psych-rock institution verges on self-indulgence for the first time.
The punk trio disbanded in 2016, but their final album serves up the chaotic blend of post-hardcore, noise rock, and Midwest emo that made them beloved.

album: Trying to Find My Next Thrill
description: On his second album, the Boston rapper embraces his strengths, grows into his voice as a writer and draws lessons from his come-up.
Melina Duterte’s second album as Jay Som sounds exploratory and playful, like a jam session among friends that’s just hit its stride.
After a brief hiatus, the restlessly creative group returns with a compelling but disjointed record about self-fulfillment.
With a voice that evokes Nina Simone’s, the 24-year-old Atlanta soul singer uses her debut album to explore post-breakup intimacies of pain and desire.
The debut project from the former member of Gayngs and Rosebuds is a frivolous soufflé of soft-rock baby-makers and disco deliria that could have been crafted any time in the last 50 years.
Balancing vaporwave’s glossy kitsch with throat-shredding metal vocals and labyrinthine sound collage, Angel Marcloid’s music is a perfect fusion of pop and pure abstraction.
The slowcore band’s knotty and fascinating third LP delves into the question of what makes daily life so unnecessarily difficult.
The TDE soul singer takes a darker turn on his second record, a sad and gauzy R&B collection full of bitterness and missed connections.
The major-label debut from the Atlanta R&B singer offers a layered, mesmerizing portrait of modern romance.
Mirabella Karyanova’s debut EP for Nina Kraviz’s Trip label pairs playful Russian-language vocal manipulation with woozy electronic pop modeled after minimal techno’s trippy specifications.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the arrival of Sean Paul, who brought dancehall with all its complexity to the masses.
This surreal, distortion-heavy power-pop album, reissued on vinyl, stands among the best of the late-’90s Elephant 6 output.
The Philadelphia band return with a glorious sheen on their pro-worker, pro-barroom rock’n’roll.
A fundraiser for Polish LGBTQIA+ organizations presents a bounty of progressive electronic music, compiling 10 hours of material from Rrose, Violet, Peder Mannerfelt, and more.
On their harrowing and strangely cleansing second album, the Brooklyn-based vocalist and poet grapples with depression, anxiety, and identity.
New band from former Ultimate Painting songwriter Jack Cooper blends introspective songwriting with churning experimentation in earnest search of a different plane of existence.
Pairing Midwestern hip-house with Los Angeles G-funk, the South Central native emphasizes subtly bumping grooves and gruff, hypnotic rhymes.
On her seventh album, Taylor Swift is a little wiser and a lot more in love. Though uneven,   is a bright, fun album with great emotional honesty.
A quiet resolve underlies the folk singer’s mesmeric Sub Pop debut, which is her sunniest and most intrepid.
St. Vincent’s sleek, streamlined production stands out from the rest of the band’s catalog, but all of the elements you first fell in love with are still here.
The Los Angeles-based producer and composer adds singing to his repertoire, setting snapshots of past romances against warm, nostalgic production.
The Fuck Buttons member’s fourth solo album channels the horrors of the surveillance state and the creeping dread of everyday life into the most aggressive music of his career.
The Atlanta label home to Migos and Lil Yachty overstuffs their new compilation with lackluster raps from stars who seem to be stuck in a loop.
The solo debut from Wye Oak member Andy Stack threads kinetic dream-pop and electronic textures into a hypnotic break-up record.
The Brooklyn indie rock institution’s seventh album is as joyous and rousing as their best efforts.
Featuring several of his acolytes,   remains a triumphant showcase for the iconoclastic Young Thug and one of his best albums to date.
The Ecuador-born songwriter’s second album is a study in time, examining aging as a continuum of death and regeneration with a light, whimsical touch.
The Vancouver-based producer/vocalist is a merciless industrial-rap experimentalist obsessed with the point where sex and death intertwine.
The Hague-based composer and pianist explores music’s transcendent qualities on an album of minimalist piano with subtle new-age overtones.

album: I Spent the Winter Writing Songs About Getting Better
description: The Brooklyn band's explosively verbal, shapeshifting, and snarky emo-pop explores how intersectional identities move within predominantly white spaces.
On his third album, Sam Hall performs lo-fi keyboard-trap doused in the same ecstasy produced by fleeting interactions with your middle-school crush.
John Cage’s notorious “silent” piece   is an exercise in listening. But a compilation of covers—from New Order, Depeche Mode, and others—proves that interpreting it is not as easy as it might seem.
On her sophomore album, the country singer name-checks Minor Threat and Against Me! while drawing inspiration from classic Hank Williams and Patsy Cline.
On their second album of the year, the ever-mutating Aussie psych-rock outfit embrace throwback thrash metal to soundtrack the end of life on Earth.
Today on Pitchfork, we are taking a critical look at the rise of Taylor Swift—from country underdog to pop superstar—with new reviews of her first five records.
Today on Pitchfork, we are taking a critical look at the rise of Taylor Swift—from country underdog to pop superstar—with new reviews of her first five records.
Today on Pitchfork, we are taking a critical look at the rise of Taylor Swift—from country underdog to pop superstar—with new reviews of her first five records.
Today on Pitchfork, we are taking a critical look at the rise of Taylor Swift—from country underdog to pop superstar—with new reviews of her first five records.
Today on Pitchfork, we are taking a critical look at the rise of Taylor Swift—from country underdog to pop superstar—with new reviews of her first five records.
Trippie Redd’s sprawling album is designed to show his versatility, but it’s not nearly wild enough to distract from its lack of coherent ideas.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a landmark of mainstream ’70s soft-rock, the peak of Linda Ronstadt’s power as a singer nonpareil.
Age has mellowed rap’s most audacious fabulist, and on the sequel to his breakout debut, he settles into his luxe sound like a pair of velvet slippers.
The excellent album from the Long Island singer-songwriter Jade Lilitri is sharp and radiant, a massively catchy guitar record about trying to walk the straight and narrow.
The UK trio’s first album since 2011 finds new life in the smooth surfaces of house music.
Equal parts manifesto and critique, the pair’s third musical collaboration pays homage to the sound and radical spirit of their West Coast home.
The sixth album from the Iowa metal mainstays has more to offer than expected and is still sometimes frustratingly short-sighted.
The meme rapper’s debut album confirms everyone’s suspicions about the relationship between viral hip-hop fame and rapping abilities.
In accordance with his label’s ethos, the Fool’s Gold co-founder connects the dots between the hip-hop and dance worlds on a space-themed record that bounces from rap to rave to electro.
On their second album, the Boston slowcore trio’s pensive, downtempo rock has grown tighter, clearer, and at times brighter.
The pop singer’s second album is looser, livelier and more ecstatic than her debut, detailing the headlong rush of falling in love.

album: Jambú e Os Míticos Sons Da Amazônia
description: This revelatory survey of the music of Northern Brazil from the 1970s and ’80s is by turns alien and familiar, sacred and profane, always raw and thrilling.
Inspired by Alfred Stieglitz’ black-and-white photographs of clouds, the Canadian ambient musician reworks piano samples into one of the most monochromatic albums of his career.
On her second album, the Nashville spitfire flits easily between country, bluegrass, and rock.

album: This Is Not a Safe Place
description: On their second post-reunion album, the shoegaze band sound emboldened, merrily tinkering with their legacy.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the calm before the storm, a long-out-of-print album from Lindsey Buckingham and Stevie Nicks before they joined Fleetwood Mac.
With a persona modeled after Eminem’s, the Michigan-born star of Christian rap recently notched his second No. 1 album. But to most of the secular world, he’s a ghost.
These six cerebral, spiky songs extract something touching and tragic from the mundanity of social media and social anxiety.

On his fourth album, Justin Vernon reassembles the familiar Bon Iver elements like a cubist collage, with his voice fearlessly front and center. The result is his most honest and forthright music ever.
The latest on the adventurous West Mineral Ltd. label finds the mysterious duo crafting something with classic ambient earmarks as well as off-kilter addenda.
Though the ethereal presence of Slowdive’s Rachel Goswell is unmistakable, the UK band’s self-titled debut is often tedious.
On his new mixtape, the Vallejo upstart sounds a little too eager to break out of his home base.
The British singer-songwriter’s third album is a singular, extraordinarily horny, and occasionally bleak pop record largely about the complexities of queer desire.
In 1969, Elvis Presley went to Las Vegas to reboot his career. With a half-century of hindsight, the performances feel both bittersweet and anticlimactic.
This odds-and-ends compilation features tracks originally released between 2010 and 2016, and presents a more vulnerable version of the pop colossus we know now.
Their latest album aims for life-or-death melodrama, but amid the layered arrangements and slick songwriting, Ra Ra Riot seem to once again have lost their sense of identity.

album: Blinded by the Light (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
description: The coming-of-age film reveals the life-changing power of some of Bruce Springsteen’s most famous songs, but its soundtrack doesn’t measure up.
The New Zealand sister duo offer a self-contained suite of dream pop, folk, and cosmic jazz that’s far more evocative than the few words they sing.
The masked UK duo crafts electronic pop that draws on hip-hop, R&B, chillwave, and psych-funk, but their immersive soundscapes leave little impression.
Duppy Gun’s latest, organized around the songs of I Jahbar, finds the international crew boldly charting their own course.
Yoni Wolf and his band switch up their approach with bite-sized songs, a visual album, and an uncharacteristic focus on the past.
On his second album, the viral rap star makes some of the most charming music of his still-young career.
Inspired by a love of fantasy and cartoons, the rapper’s debut full-length is simultaneously playful and sincere, confident and anxious.
The live album captures a night of the exuberant collaboration Karin Dreijer fostered with the   stage production, adding volume and dimensionality to old and new songs alike.
The breakbeat revivalist returns to well-worn rave tropes, yielding diminishing returns.
Independent rap vet Young Dolph trades bars with fellow Memphis native Key Glock on an album that channels the city’s iconic sound.
On his latest double album, the Vallejo vet remains free-flowing, wise, hilarious, and unstoppable.
On their second EP, the Atlanta trio swirls post-punk, drone, and math rock into self-described “deconstructionist pop.”
The Chicago rapper fills his debut with raps about...making it in rap. It’s rarely endearing or interesting.
On her debut album, the young viral star moves beyond the lo-fi bedroom-pop of her early recordings and into a restrained, detailed style of songwriting all her own.
On their debut, My Morning Jacket discovered the heavy reverb that would make them legendary.
On his first full-length under the Leech alias, Brian Foote dissects his electronic music until it evokes the wide-open spaces of early drum’n’bass.

album: Stevie Wonder’s Journey Through the Secret Life of Plants
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Stevie Wonder’s sprawling, misunderstood double album about the interconnections of ecology and the black experience.
Balancing lush ambience and sharp electronics, this cross-continental collaboration addresses the climate crisis with musical interpretations of land under assault.
The native Kentuckian shows a flair for rough-hewn honky-tonk and piercing details on his latest release, produced by Sturgill Simpson.
The Baltimore ambient musician uses sitar and synthesizers to investigate folkloric narratives from around the world.
Fucked Up guitarist Ben Cook is also a pop poet, and the third album from his nostalgic indie-pop project recalls the grainy, jangly melodicism of college rock.
Elaborating on music he composed for the British TV series “Kiri,” the Warp Records mainstay vacillates between too-tasteful acoustic arrangements and abrasive provocation.
Temporarily abandoning the guitar, the prolific garage rocker channels his indulgences and comes away with an unusually focused album.
With live instrumentation and a hard-won sense of optimism, the GothBoiClique artist’s official debut makes a case for itself in the pop-punk lineage.
Chance’s sprawling, 77-minute “debut” is an exuberant and often wonderful celebration of love and family that struggles to bring depth to his newlywed dad-raps.

Linda McCartney’s first and only studio album was released to resounding silence shortly after her death in 1998. But she and Paul shared a musical chemistry as singular as Yoko and John’s, and as emblematic of their shared interests.
The rowdy and promising debut from this London septet is further evidence of the London jazz scene’s vitality.

album: Once Upon a Time ... in Hollywood (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
description: The music is a highlight of Quentin Tarantino’s new film, an undeniable, oft-disquieting mixtape of golden-age rock’n’roll, radio DJ patter, and period-specific commercials.
The Nigerian singer blends the personal and political into a new benchmark of Afro-fusion music.
Unlike some of R&B’s showier personalities, the Chicago singer makes do with a great voice, laid-back vibes, and a classic sound that’s neither brazenly modern nor self-consciously retro.
The Seattle pop-punk band shape-shifts through ’90s alt-rock but sacrifices its personality in the process.

album: Woodstock – Back to the Garden: The Definitive 50th Anniversary Archive
description: Fifty years after the three-day concert made rock’n’roll history, a gargantuan, 38-disc set attempts to tell the full story of the event for the very first time.
The Brooklyn rapper makes good on the promise of “Welcome to the Party” with a debut full of the hardest, dirtiest tracks he can manage.
This focused and forceful 2013 live set showed the reunited grunge band looking to their future before the tragic death of lead singer Chris Cornell.
The fabled noise-rock outfit paint an ugly world on their second post-reunion release, but they have never sounded freer or more purposeful.
The Washington, D.C. trio make visceral, minimal punk that’s as stripped down as a roadkill carcass, and almost as gross.
On his third album, Jake Ewald reunites with former Modern Baseball bandmate Ian Farmer to explore pared-down folk-rock. It’s the furthest from MoBo he’s ever sounded.
A sequel to his 2017 tape shows the one-time rising star of Chicago drill again offering a sobering depiction of life outside of rap myths.
The 21-year-old bedroom-pop artist’s major-label debut displays shaggy charm and an eclecticism that’s still confined to the more pleasant parts of the color wheel.
Occasionally corny and self-serious, Cordae's redemption tale shows a promising voice bursting into the mainstream.
The debut solo album from Pavo Pavo’s Eliza Bagg, a collection of pop songs with subtle experimental undertones, is her most outré release to date.
A sought-after roller-disco anthem from 1983 makes for a tantalizing hybrid of boogie, electro, and house, and lays the foundation for artists from Chromeo to Dâm-Funk.
The Tokyo jazz-fusion quintet specializes in disorienting twists and turns, offsetting chaos with an unmistakable sense of fun.
The debut full-length from the “Drew Barrymore” singer isn’t designed for conscious, focused listening. This is music for poolsides and basements.

Emily Sprague’s folk music turns solitude into an evocation of spirits. Her latest album as Florist grapples with change, death, and uncertainty with some of the most arresting songwriting of the year.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Chan Marshall’s spellbinding fourth album, an intimate and feverish masterpiece from the singer-songwriter.

On her torrential second album, Kristin Hayter creates a murderous amalgam of opera, metal, and noise that uses her classical training like a Trojan Horse, burning misogyny to ash from its Judeo-Christian roots.
Featuring members of Priests and Downtown Boys, the D.C. punk collective’s debut is a driving and tenacious record that never loses its feral appeal.
The best album of the Philadelphia band’s deep and underappreciated catalog dares to ask what comes after indie rock.

album: Live at Alexandra Palace London, 8th and 9th May 2019
description: Kieran Hebden’s new live album reminds us that he is a stellar performer, not just a producer.
Tony Molina’s fat-free, minute-long missives give you everything you might want in a rock song in a third of the time. This rarities collection is the perfect entry point.
Tilting his gaze toward the heavens once again, the Detroit electronic icon delivers an ambient-techno concept album exploring the moon’s pull on the human imagination.
The latest album from the child star turned Star Child can be pretty in a tuned-out sort of way, but her psychedelic soul music is no closer to showing us who she really is.
The duo’s wild-eyed genre mishmash covers chiptuned pop-punk, chintzy trance synths, and the closely mic’d intimacy of indie pop—sometimes all in the same song.
The Chicago trumpeter with hip-hop and indie-rock bona fides steps out as a bandleader, shepherding 18 musicians across a complex, soulful album that celebrates interconnectedness.
Ostensibly a sequel to  , these unreleased songs from Nas’ latter-day output were pulled from the cutting room floor.
The Australian rapper returns with her first album in five years, sounding not just unrepentant but also tediously uninterested in any kind of growth whatsoever.

album: Remind Me: The Classic Elektra Recordings 1978-1984
description: The jazz and R&B legend's songs have been sampled by everyone from Will Smith to Prince Paul. This compilation shows her immaculate work on its own.
The 21-year-old Bronx native belongs to an exciting new generation remaking NYC rap in their own image. On his third album, he grapples with present-day poverty and everyday life.
The latest mixtape from the young Detroit rapper takes scamming to the next level.
Beyoncé parlays her role in Disney’s   to put out a fine companion album that showcases today’s African stars.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the debut album from Mase, an icon of the shiny suit era who turned the Bad Boy throne into a recliner.
Sordid family history has long been the source of the Houston rapper’s most resonant storytelling. His latest project is such a major leap in craft and style, it becomes a superpower.
The daring Chicago pop artist explores resilience and hard-won triumphs against a backdrop of hatred and brutality.

album: Tiny Changes: A Celebration of Frightened Rabbit’s ‘The Midnight Organ Fight’
description: Completed before the death of Frightened Rabbit’s Scott Hutchison, this tribute to the band’s most celebrated album takes a relaxed, occasionally unconventional approach.
The Russian electronic musician offers a mind-melting and hypnotic take on techno.
The 1983 film score aspired to the weightlessness of outer space. A remastered edition adds an album’s worth of new songs that reflect how far we’ve come from the Apollo missions’ optimism.
The New York singer-songwriter shifts from acoustic folk into potent pop-punk that recalls both Hop Along and Titus Andronicus.
Following a standout contribution to Berlin label PAN’s   compilation, the Stockholm producer delivers an impressive debut album that’s both gloomy and delightful.
As far as concept albums about magical, abnormally sized severed heads go, this is a pretty breezy listen.
The Toronto death metal quartet pushes outward into new territory on its darkest, strangest album yet.
In the wake of a family tragedy, the producer crafts a genuinely transportive work, seamlessly mixing Jersey club with Middle Eastern instruments.
Jay Reatard’s early band Lost Sounds veered from rock‘n’roll primitivism into synth-punk futurism, but the result wasn’t dance music—it was panic music.

album: Don’t You Think You've Had Enough?
description: The Los Angeles punk duo get sober and burn off the fog of their last release for a crisper, punchier sound.
Though their 1994 album became most famous for a surprise hit remix, Tracey Thorn and Ben Watt’s spare, pensive style never sounded more fully realized than here.
Today on Pitchfork, we are publishing new reviews of five important early Stereolab records, each one a rung on the ladder of one of the most exceptional and historically influential bands.
Today on Pitchfork, we are publishing new reviews of five important early Stereolab records, each one a rung on the ladder of one of the most exceptional and historically influential bands.
The pop star’s compilation features Cardi B, Chance the Rapper, and Stormzy in a sometimes nice but hopelessly transparent attempt at a hip-hop crossover.
The Montreal singer-songwriter’s debut album uses heartbreak as the springboard for an innovative brand of indie rock that’s both fiery and introspective.
Today on Pitchfork, we are publishing new reviews of five important early Stereolab records, each one a rung on the ladder of one of the most exceptional and historically influential bands.
The southern rapper’s latest project captures him the same way he always is: perfectly likable, admirably sincere, predictably dependable and dependably predictable.
Dev Hynes’ new mixtape feels light and loose, a pre-production sketchbook presented as a charmingly finished product with the help of several key guests.
Today on Pitchfork, we are publishing new reviews of five important early Stereolab records, each one a rung on the ladder of one of the most exceptional and historically influential bands.
David Berman’s first new music in over a decade is a marvelous collection of heartbreak, grief, and bitterness. His careful writing has never sounded so exacting or direct.
Sternberg’s debut balances stark themes of suicidal ideation, abject hopelessness, and self-hatred with whimsy and redemptive tenderness.
Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Aaliyah’s final album, her masterpiece.
While the brooding pop singer can’t always shake the anodyne songwriting that plagued her past work,   is still Banks’ best album to date.

album: Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?
description: The Liverpool four-piece’s debut experiments liberally with pop’s conventions, taking a collage-like approach to chopped samples, ghostly harmonies, and pedal-driven guitars and keyboards.
The frenetic, sample-heavy album from Eric André’s clown alter-ego is hard to take seriously, which is probably the point.
Today on Pitchfork, we are publishing new reviews of five important early Stereolab records, each one a rung on the ladder of one of the most exceptional and historically influential bands.
Everyone in hip-hop roots for Atlanta rapper Key! His summery follow-up to last year’s break-out   offers more evidence why.

album: Stranger Things: Soundtrack From the Netflix Original Series, Season 3
description: Madonna, “Weird Al” Yankovic, and a bizarre remix of the Who are all part of a soundtrack that speaks to the usual critiques of the frothy, summertime sci-fi tale.
The Malaysian-born, L.A.-based musician moves away from folk-pop into simmering R&B, with features from Tyler, the Creator, Little Simz, and others.
The Toronto singer croons his way into a sapiosexual world of love and philosophy, though not without controversy.
Kameron Bogges makes one-man black metal that charts the hellish exhilarations and debilitating lows of bipolar disorder.
An album’s worth of dub versions of last year’s   offer playful, if inessential, tweaks to the Houston band’s psych-funk sound.
The metal band’s latest album retains the sludgy ferocity of its best work while opening up to include elements of shoegaze and dream pop, to mixed success.
The methodical arrangements and uncomfortably close whispers of the experimental French musician, poet, and visual artist bring us further inside her surreal world.
The first spoils of the fabled Dreamville sessions feature J. Cole and his label mostly thriving in a collaborative environment.
The experimental ambient musician's latest work is his most beatific and generous yet. It features a rotating cast of musicians, and feels like it is hovering off of the ground.
The solo debut from folk singer Alexandra Sauser-Monnig reveals her effortless skill as a songwriter as she delivers an homage to the betwixt and between of a relationship in its twilight.
A new installment in Parlophone’s ongoing reissue series revisits an oft-bootlegged 1969 session with fellow folkie John Hutchinson: literal bedroom tapes, but still revelatory.
Looping and manipulating voices into strange, lumbering beatbox fugues, Inga Copeland undercuts expectation at every turn.
The young polymath’s latest album is mostly a slog, the sound of an artist with a blurry vision and too many resources at his disposal.
The Albany emo band offer us a fuck-up’s masterpiece, a hero’s journey following a guy who might conquer the world if he could leave his couch.

The pop star’s debut is decadent and deeply silly, with songs delivered by the kind of person who uses even the slightest bit of emotional turmoil as an excuse to immerse herself in sex, drugs, and money.
Bobby Krlic (aka the Haxan Cloak) scores Ari Aster’s nightmarish new film  , and the result is transfixing, gorgeous, and terrifying at once.
The latest from the Melbourne electronic duo is a dawdler’s paradise, a daydream mapped to MIDI.
This Moog synth album from 1976 was meant to help houseplants grow. Jurys out on that, but it became a cult classic nonetheless.
The two urbano superstars bro down over trap and dembow beats on a goofy but incredibly fun summertime album.
On their third album, the first release on their own label, the Jamaican group continues to find their post-diasporic, outernational voice; this time with vocals.
The soundtrack to the superstar boy band’s mobile app game is the most inessential BTS-affiliated project to date.
Azniv Korkejian’s folk music boasts a surreal calm and a lived-in glow that masks turmoil just outside the frame.
Erin Birgy’s fifth album feels like the heartfelt expression of a uniquely weird viewpoint. It flits from groovy jazz to psych-pop to sylvan folk with freaky glee.
The Australian multi-instrumentalist pushes his wispy electroacoustic music into warmer, more melodic territory.

album: The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a globetrotting fantasia on the Nintendo 64 that remains the high-water mark for video game music.
Eight years after “Huzzah,” the Brooklyn rapper is back on his own label, back on his own terms, and just as defiant and provocative as ever.
On her debut, the French-American musician offers a broken heart, a jaded eye, oceans of surf-rock reverb, and a Van Dyke Parks cameo.
Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Sigur Rós’ elemental 1999 breakthrough.
An artist known for his photographs turns his hand to music; his hazy, lo-fi productions strive for the analog warmth of his portraits, but they lack his pictures’ intimacy and empathy.
The German house producer’s sound is warm and welcoming, fusing four-to-the-floor grooves with the spacious atmospheres of Jamaican dub.
With subtle electronic production tugging at the edges of her fingerpicked folk, the California singer-songwriter peers at the dark side of motherhood.
The experimental New York duo morph into a crack ensemble on their wide-ranging new double album, blurring genres and record-store categories.
On their second album as a duo, Madlib and Freddie Gibbs pull themselves deeper into one another’s worlds.
The Austin-based duo don’t shy away from signifiers of the past, conjuring the sounds of the late 1960s and early 1970s without succumbing to pure nostalgic pandering.
The elusive Detroit producer returns after a years-long mysterious absence with a burning, urgent, and immersive new LP.
The Chicago band’s first full-length is a collection of sweet, brightly colored love songs from the mind of an acid enthusiast, woven from a small used record store’s worth of influences.
A live recording from 2016 captures the avant-rock titans jamming on the edge of oblivion.

album: Taxi Sampler 01: Rhythms & Vibes From the Spirit of Young Africa
description: The eclectic comp from the Rome-based collective Crudo Volta is a solid primer for those new to gqom, Afrobass, and Ethiopiyawi Electronic.
The Korean DJ’s contribution to the storied mix series looks beyond the dancefloor, offering a tantalizing peek at her influences.

album: Digital Kabar: Electronic Maloya From La Réunion Since 1980
description: A traditional, once-suppressed style from La Réunion, a small island off the coast of Madagascar, meets the electronic music of the 21st century.

album: Text While Driving If You Want to Meet God
description: The Frank Ocean collaborator lays his hard drive bare, pulling back the curtain to reveal the scattered pieces of recorded music littering his cutting-room floor.
On their first new album in six years, the longrunning emo outfit take ownership of their sound. Even the quietest moments sit with jagged nerves and lingering tension.
The rap zeitgeist has mostly left iLoveMakonnen behind, but his first major-label release in years shows a taste of the pop star he could still become.

album: All the Mirrors In the House (Home Recordings 1979 - 1986)
description: Fueled by the curiosity of the untutored mind, Warren Defever’s collection of childhood recordings is wispy, mercurial, and improbably good.
Hatchie's platonic ideal of dream pop goes down a bit too easy, like another rewatch of a John Hughes film.
After an 11-year hiatus, the first album from Jack White’s other other band floats in weightless, haughty bliss through a perpetual 2008.
The Bronx rapper drags himself back and forth between agony and breakthrough on his latest record, the fullest and most realized album of the 20-year-old’s career.
The third solo album from Thom Yorke is the first one that feels complete without his band behind him. It floats through the uneasy space between societal turmoil and internal monologue.
Will Toledo takes Car Seat Headrest out of the bedroom and into a 1000-seat theater near you on the band’s first major live album.
Produced by Mark Ronson and performed and co-written by a suite of female vocalists, this compilation explores the many shades of heartbreak in current pop.
Playboi Carti’s go-to producer goes solo, crooning in AutoTune over his blissfully simple earworm beats.
This is an album by the Black Keys called “Let’s Rock.” That's what it does.
Experimental pianist Nathan Phillips flits seamlessly between wobbly electronic pop, soaring post-rock grandeur, and ambient minimalism.
Inspired by house music’s roots in the queer and black communities of her hometown, the Chicago DJ delivers a DJ set joyfully at odds with the dominant strains of contemporary dance music.
Tough, upfront, and often bruisingly physical,   is the New York producer’s most substantial piece of work by a considerable margin.
On their third record, the Philly band has achieved a balance between seething chaos and quietly devastating vulnerability. It’s one of the best punk rock records of the year.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the oft-overshadowed debut from indie rock icons, a smaller and more intimate look into the mercurial world of Jeff Mangum.
On their second album, the cheerfully subversive L.A. art-punks critique societal norms as they revel in their own absurdity (and saxophone).
Post-rock, space rock, prog rock, psychedelic rock, grungy Alice in Chains-eyeing hard rock—it’s all here, and since it’s Baroness, it works.
Culled from the band’s sessions at Maida Vale Studios in 1994 and 2004, this double-LP that captures, in great fidelity, the acerbic personality and power of Steve Albini’s trio.
The New York duo jump-starts iconic disco label West End Records with a love letter to classic dance, but the mood is strangely sour.
Where Titus Andronicus once made great statements out of bloat, on their sixth album they do it with refreshing brevity.
Old age suits the country singer well. On his latest album—featuring three newly penned tunes—Willie sings with a kind of chagrinned humor, as if nobody is more surprised by his longevity than he is.
Released just days after Philippe Zdar’s accidental death, the duo’s fifth album marks a joyous return to the emotive, immaculately produced house music of their early years.
The London guitar band’s debut is twitchy, hair-raising, always on the move. They harken back to a more esoteric era of indie with a magnetic and dazzling style.
The instrumental metal quartet’s first album in six years grapples directly with loss and grief, channeling dueling guitars and pummeling rhythms into a dire, haunted sound.
GoldLink’s second album stretches far beyond his home in the DMV. It is a confluence of black music; hip-hop tracing its way back to the universal sounds of Africa.
The Russian duo’s frenetic approach is more techno egg-and-spoon race than tech-house marathon, packed with improbable sounds, intriguing blind alleys, and eyebrow-raising quirks.

album: The Complete Birth of the Cool
description: A modern-jazz touchstone that opened the door to the sleek introspection and sophisticated aplomb of 1950s cool jazz gets an exquisite and essential vinyl reissue.
The Swedish producer and frequent Robyn collaborator offers an ambitious three-album suite of understated, occasionally disquieting techno nocturnes.
Claire Cronin’s latest record connects her lifelong love of horror movies to her simple, creaky songs.
The band’s seventh album is compulsively listenable, oddly moving, and stranger than it first appears.
The Atlanta rapper finally steps out of Young Thug’s shadow and showcases his own style and versatility.
The rising London rapper flexes his versatility with a musically diverse set that feels more like a major studio debut than the mixtape it’s billed as.
The Chicago rapper and singer makes a name for herself with an airy, flexible voice that flows effortlessly between the sensuous and the sorrowful.

album: Turn Off the News (Build a Garden)
description: The son of Willie Nelson has led a charmed life, playing with Neil Young and inspiring Bradley Cooper in  . His own band’s throwback roots-rock toes the line of escapism.
The New York City psych-rock quartet’s debut full-length beckons the listener with dreamy keyboards, twinkling guitar, and a recognizable buzz of stoic anxiety.
It took more than a decade to follow up  , but its successor reveals musicians who’ve learned to corral swarms of instruments and styles into a newly complex sound.
A dreamy, bucolic ambient LP, full of lush textures and birdsong, along with a number of other pleasant surprises.
Kevin Devine and Manchester Orchestra’s Andy Hull used to record collaborations that sounded like reworkings of their respective catalogs, but they’ve finally articulated what this band is about.
The songs on the debut EP from the viral rap and country star do not even come close to the pure magic of “Old Town Road.”
The St. Louis metalpunks put their politics at the forefront of their music—except they’ve also got riffs, and they can write the hell out of a catchy, confrontational punk song.
The Bronx-born DJ melds genres at breakneck speed on a disconsolate and deeply personal breakup record.
On his new EP, Noel Gallagher breaks free—a little—from his six-string to embrace the Big Beat of his youth.
On the follow-up to her 2017 album  , the Swedish composer delves even deeper into microtonal interplay, balancing heady theoretical terrain with a rare emotional resonance.
Madonna’s 14th album feels stretched thin all over the globe, layered with an ambitious concept that ends up muddled and convoluted.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the classic rock staple from a band who rebounded from tragedy to record one of the biggest albums ever made.
Interpolating field recordings and birdsong, the Cuban-born jazz pianist's fourth album explores the sounds of his home country with warmth and fervor.
A reissue of the Downtown fixture’s 1981 debut album is a reminder that despite his striking look, campy repertoire, and operatic range, the onetime Bowie collaborator was no novelty act.

album: Bob Dylan: Rolling Thunder Revue: The 1975 Live Recordings
description: A mammoth, 14-CD box set released to accompany Martin Scorcese’s documentary captures the 1975 tour in all its ragged glory.
The Detroit indie rocker’s second album fluctuates between alt-rock and garage pop, turning up her amp and doubling down on her uncompromising style.
The Swedish EDM superstar’s posthumous final album purports to reveal Tim Bergling as he’s never been seen, but the scrum of co-writers and guest singers leaves more questions than answers.
A slight and unwaveringly safe 30 minutes, Yeasayer’s latest goes down easier than anything the band has ever done, while making less of an impression.
His latest EP proves he’s still a master of melancholic detail, but thematically and sonically, the Atlanta superstar has hit a wall.
The Pulitzer Prize-winning composer’s latest installment in his   trilogy is expansive and inviting. The piece explores resonance and the way sounds mutate, stick in our heads, or just disappear.
The former teen heartthrobs’ first album in almost 10 years is by no means extraordinary, but it’s a respectable showing from a group that has long deserved more respect than they got.
A peerless storyteller gazes deep into domestic life and offers a long, sun-warmed double album that is a highlight of his career.

album: Sonic Youth: Battery Park, NYC: July 4, 2008
description: Three years before they split, at an Independence Day concert in a downtown park, the band tore through its earliest work with the polish of seasoned pros.
Lush, heady, and shot through with an undercurrent of wistful contemplation, producer Brian Piñeyro’s “deep reggaetón” sound can’t be called lo-fi anymore.
On their Relapse debut, the infernal Full of Hell crack apart metal genres like oracle bones.
Bruce Springsteen returns with elegiac and wise songwriting conjuring the golden expanse of the American West; it’s his best studio album in years.
Drawing on its members’ diverse backgrounds and distinguished resumes—including work with Broadcast, Gruff Rhys, and Zongamin—the London band tilts its psychedelic pop toward a utopian future.
Polo G blends pop and drill with ease and delivers a standout Chicago street rap debut that is meticulously crafted and honestly told.
With their true Norwegian black metal days behind them and nothing left to prove, the longrunning duo trumpet their joyful debt to classic heavy metal.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the lo-fi acoustic recordings of Roky Erickson, a rare glimpse at his stark and transcendent songwriting.
On her second album, singer and songwriter Johanne Swanson is wiser, steadier, and more willing to explore. Her music now feels like an expression of emotional epiphanies.
The twin-brother jazz duo are experts at channeling the sounds of light and ease, and there’s something almost alchemical about their mutual precision.
The electronic musician and veteran soundtrack composer turns his interpretive abilities to a single episode of Charlie Brooker’s dystopian Netflix series, to subtle yet compelling effect.
The low-end mastermind behind the Bug and King Midas Sound turns his gut-rumbling frequencies and queasy atmospheres to the terrors of new parenthood.
For a rock band who excels at high-intensity drama, their latest is set of mid-tempo snoozers that are over-refined, hermetically sealed, and safe.
The singer-songwriter and pianist writes quietly epic songs about heartbreak, determination, and loneliness.
Guitarist and bandleader Ellen Kempner’s third record breaks down the walls around her wiry, anxious riffs, opening space for levity and the thrill of new love.
Jacob Long’s vaporous, lo-fi ambient tracks feel like snapshots of stillness made of moving parts.
Unreleased at the time, the Japanese guitarist's elemental free jazz opus provides the missing link between Albert Ayler, Merzbow, and Acid Mothers Temple.
The first EP of a forthcoming trilogy from the pop icon is all over the place. It misuses her talents and makes for a largely unrewarding listen.
The Uruguayan-American singer-songwriter’s latest is a charmingly loose grab bag, dotted with field recordings and snippets of sampled conversation.
The Australian bedroom-pop artist’s third album demonstrates that her attention to how her songs start, end, and connect has never been keener or better controlled.
Hearing Prince sing these songs that he gave to other performers brings you close to the pulse of his artistry: transgressive, funky, sexy, a testament to his genius even in the form of demos.
The decade’s most tantalizing pop enigma officially releases a trove of unfinished material that was originally leaked online six years ago.
The German producer offers his prettiest, silkiest, and most poignant minimal electronic music ever.
The comedian and musician brings his dry absurdity and taste for 1970s singer-songwriters to a novel venture: a fake breakup album.
Neither rigidly authentic nor conspicuously modern, the North Carolina folk scholar honors the past through transformation rather than reinvention.
The South Florida rapper puts on for his city and delivers the best, most dynamic, and altogether hardest album of his career.
Hannes Norrvide's long-running coldwave synth project breaks into the greener pastures of Depeche Mode-style new wave.
The Seoul duo taps into devotional music’s focused intensity in trance-inducing pieces that draw on new age, krautrock, and folk.
The Canadian composer turns from electroacoustic minimalism to contemplative, deeply focused compositions for piano, organ, voice, and strings.
Over field recordings sourced from the Mexico of Antonin Artaud’s travels, the New York singer gives voice to the French poet’s hallucinogenic visions.
The more relaxed, country-adjacent follow-up to 2017’s   pairs pastoral modes with surreal meditations on a warming world.
The Chicago-based improvisational artist layers politically charged sound collages over drum machines and a children’s choir. The result is uplifting activist jazz for tumultuous times.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Pavement’s divisive final album, full of clamor and clarity that presaged the end of the underground.
Matthew Cooper's second solo piano record in 15 years glows with a childlike wonder underscored by mature regret.
The omnivorous Nigerian rapper-singer makes smoothly effortless genre hybrids that feel like everywhere and nowhere all at once.
The Montreal ambient musician’s albums all resemble each other in their broad strokes and abiding stillness. They are beautiful, terrifying, and bittersweet all at once.
Though the Seattle band would produce more focused efforts,   is a fascinating document of nascent indie rock that sounds revelatory 25 years later.
The L.A.-based Sprague steps away from her indie pop trio Florist for rippling, patient, and redemptive ambient drone works for modular synthesizers.

The music from Elton John’s life sinks into the uncanny valley with a studio band, a substitute singer, and a silver-screen production that misses the finer points of the legendary performer’s career.
The 21-year-old singer-songwriter’s third album is serene folk-pop with a mellow soul tinge and the melancholy clarity of someone twice her age.
The Scotland-based duo delight in controlled chaos, interweaving arguments and anxieties with their most exuberant work to date.
On the follow-up to her debut solo album, the former iamamiwhoami member tilts her off-kilter electro pop toward compellingly dystopian visions.
The singer and guitarist’s debut solo album offers an introspective blend of R&B, hip-hop, & lo-fi pop but feels reluctant to claim the spotlight.
The minimalist drone-riff masters pare away excess and focus on the seismic repetition that made their best work so resonant, creating a new peak in their long discography.
The Malian producer employs ngoni and other regional sounds in hip-hop-inspired fusions that, at their best, suggest a West African beat tape.
On their first album as a collective, Beast Coast attempt to move beyond the boom-bap revivalism that made them famous.
The Congolese American songwriter and guitarist’s debut EP winds in circles, tracing vast spaces that couch thorny emotional quagmires.
The consistent Memphis rapper continues his workmanlike grind to the top.
After years spent trading on a bulletproof back catalog and eccentric persona, the Jamaican titan teams up with UK dub heavyweight Adrian Sherwood for a welcome return to form.
Three years after he galvanized a new class of UK rappers, the grime MC tries to meet the high bar he set for himself.
The Dutch quartet undercut their perky, grunge-lite melodies with just the right amount of pop-fuzz aggression.
The California surf-garage rockers extend their recent series of EPs, and succumb to their own sense of anhedonia.
The debut album from the Iranian-Swedish artist offers a fascinatingly dark take on romantic love, filled with images of violence and devastation.
Morrissey and some (barely audible) high-profile guests rework 12 of his favorite ’60s and ’70s songs by American artists to mixed results.
Reissued on vinyl some 40 years after its initial release, Don Cherry’s sprawling, free, ecstatic masterwork defined what came to be known as “world” music.
The former Wild Beasts singer embarks on a new direction on his soul-searching solo debut, stripping back his songwriting to a reverent hush.
The first collaborative full-length by producers Machinedrum and Jimmy Edgar bounces across genres and eras, but the real magic comes from the guest vocalists.
Reinvigorated with a whole host of new members, the metal outfit prove there's plenty of life left in their road-trip rock.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the misanthropic pop perfection of the indie British band’s sixth and best album.
